titStmt.title: Spoken material from respondent Chris -- an electronic transcription

pubStmt.address: 13 Banbury Road, Oxford OX2 6NN U.K. Telephone: +44 1865 273280 Facsimile: +44 1865 273275 Internet mail: natcorp@oucs.ox.ac.uk
pubStmt.avail:
THIS TEXT IS AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT THE WORLD only as part of the British National Corpus at nominal charge FOR ACADEMIC RESEARCH PURPOSES SUBJECT TO A SIGNED END USER LICENCE HAVING BEEN RECEIVED BY OXFORD UNIVERSITY COMPUTING SERVICES, from whom forms and supporting materials are available.
THIS TEXT IS NOT AVAILABLE FOR COMMERCIAL RESEARCH AND EXPLOITATION unless terms have first been agreed with the BNC Consortium Exploitation Committee. Apply in the first instance to Oxford University Computing Services.
It is your responsibility, as a user, to ensure that an End User Licence is in place. For your information, the Terms of the End User Licence are set out in the corpus header, which is likely to have a file name similar to "corphdr" or "CORPHDR".
Distribution of any part of the corpus under the terms of the Licence must include a copy of the corpus header. Distribution of this corpus text under the terms of the Licence must include this header embodying this notice.
THE EXACT CONDITIONS OF USE FOR THIS TEXT ARE NOT CURRENTLY KNOWN TO THE ARCHIVING AGENCY. PLEASE CONTACT THE DATA CAPTURE AGENCY NAMED IN THIS HEADER FOR FURTHER INFORMATION.

encDesc.projDesc: See the project description in the corpus header for information about the British National Corpus project.
encDesc.refsDecl: Canonical references in the British National Corpus are to text segment (<s>) elements, and are constructed by taking the value of the n attribute of the <cdif> element containing the target text, and concatenating a dot separator, followed by the value of the n attribute of the target <s> element.

Age: 44 Name: Lynda Occupation: export assistant

respStmt.name: dominic

s.w: It's the best thing of course so It's a very weird thing to be doing really isn't it?

unclear.w: You can leave it there if you want even though it's the ladies
club house just to the left.

s.w: There's certainly a fancy er club house there isn't it?
What's what's this fancy building here David?

pause.w: why we can't get on there, on the door

s.w: Yes there's quite a lay out in the main building.
It used to be about the best bowling green in the in this part of the country.
No there's one there there's one here.
Over there that's behind me that's
I am not sure whether it's those certainly where you can see the right players .
Eileen's husband is the leading light in the bowls.
And is that ah er another cricket team altogether or what?
I think he he had a heart attack recently.

unclear.w: I think he is off of it now but I think he must be quite a leading light

s.w: Now, now I'm there and there aren't I?
Now if you were using this this is what we would do.
It's probably erm, yeah I think you'd probably have a shot at your yellow.
Doesn't matter if you go off because you could come up behind it.
Lynda wasn't here yesterday when er out.
You'll have to warn her about it.
Well I don't think it actually needs warning about.
I think it inhibits some people but she will explain.
You saw the sheet didn't you?
It's irritating cos the clip won't go on the shirt.
Is that the kind they wear on the television?
Why do you , why doesn't it work then?
Well it's, the shirt just seems to be too fine for it.
Oh that's Saturday not Sunday is it?
Very irritating because er if only I'd approached David earlier as I'd intended to.
Previous weekend they had an open day at er Dulwich Croquet Club.

pause.w: So all were invited to go along.

s.w: Of course I was on Sunday, yes indeed.

pause.w: Yes I couldn't fit in much croquet then could I?
The implication was that it was going to be a bit warmer today wasn't it?

s.w: I think the sun might come out a little later, I don't know about warmer but
it's certainly going to be overcast now.

pause.w: Thank you.
David and were agreeing last night how much they like the road.

s.w: I must say I don't think twice now about opening that window whereas before I only did it reluctantly because of all the dust .

ptr.w: Because of the dust flying in .

s.w: She too was saying that she had an urge to go down with her broom and sweep up the these building works.

pause.w: Right.
I'm gonna have some breakfast, aren't you?

s.w: They started off on grapefruit down there.
I've never seen such dry grapefruit.
It's such, such a time wasting procedure when you've got to take things back.
It's the same sort we had before that have been so good.
And the last couple of weeks I bought the cheaper ones.
And that was forty eight pence for one grapefruit because it was pink.
Doesn't even look pink, does it?
I don't think you have to take it back, I didn't take that chicken back to Safeway's if you remember.
Didn't take, didn't bother with the chicken.
And she didn't, she scarcely even looked at the label.
She took my word for it.
Unfortunately because it, it was a special sell today job with a reduction off others I didn't get much money back.
And then went and bought another fresh chicken had to pay even more money for it.
Well it's incredible how little mail, and there's nothing on fax or telex either.
They're all on holiday perhaps half term.
Well don't bother, we'll take it back.

pause.w: Will you have toast?
Cake?
Sorry, will you have some toast?

s.w: Did you see that erm letter in the paper the other day about the, the introduction of sliced bread because there's been a bit of a correspondence about it?
Yes sixty years ago or something.
And it's five sixteenths of an inch thick by ordinary buttering and half an inch thick for toast.
And about nineteen twenty eight or something wasn't it?
I was going to write to Long Tall Sally can't make up my mind if I should or I shouldn't but it has got those little
Unfortunately it's got a sort of general grubbiness to it as well, hasn't it?

pause.w: But that is because it doesn't come white any more when you wash it.

s.w: Thank you for getting this tomato juice specially from Safeway's.
When I go on half term I ought to all things.
Not enough change in your rate.
I feel clearer in my mind about which is a help.
And I don't feel clear of things to do which is very miserable
Well you're not doing your reports till after that time are you?
No they have to be in by the twenty sixth of June.
And the ten days after open day are going to be mad.
Twenty six days, yes, ten days.
You've got sixteen days to do them in in theory.
Well I won't have really will I if
Is that the earlier day you all complained about?
And we asked for an extra ten days.
At the moment we've got three.
Did you get any explanations why it was all required in earlier?
She just feels she wanted the time to do it in her time.
As long as you don't do it too often.
Don't do it too often just call the tune without justifying it.

pause.w: Do you think that in all schools the head always looked at all the reports?
When I was at school they hadn't signed them.
I suspect Mrs feels she ought to be signing them not the
What a funny idea this queue down parks isn't it?
Did you see that thing on television last night?

s.w: I'm interested there were women mixed in with them.
Look at this lovely picture of this High Commissioner in Sri Lanka who's been booted out in his Morris Minor.
Somebody is about to set up

unclear.w: convertible by the look of it, still.

s.w: Mm about to set up a factory in Sri Lanka to make Morris Minor parts.
Will they find him another job now?
What do they do then then?
Well he's employed by the Foreign Office.
So will they send him somewhere else?
Or they'll keep him in London.

pause.w: after Washington.

s.w: He'll probably merge back into the Department of Transport.
Might do something else in the environment.
Oh there was some talk of going somewhere else.
Well I mean, not an offer but
I don't know if , but it's on the cards that one could.
Roy's idea was that er might get some highly paid job in industry.

unclear.w: bit addictive with this at times.

s.w: It's, it's sitting down that's addictive is it?
Having breakfast when you're sitting down.
You mean you might get into a good habit?
I must say I like it.

pause.w: Erm go without lunch to make up for it.

s.w: Oh it's just me that's got to give up lunch is it?
Well you could actually have two meals today, for a change.
That, that special orange and something honey marmalade.
Sweet orange marmalade with cider in.
It was sweet, but it was pleasant.
Couldn't taste the cider could you?
My home-made of three years ago.
I think Lizzie's marmalade was particularly addictive.
Oh I did, mm, I liked that.
We haven't tried Jack's have we?
Well he's never given us a pot mean devil.
It's about the one thing a year he does do and crows about.
Well I expect his family dispose of it nicely for him.
Oh yes, yes I do believe he's given Andrew a pot to take home.
He's still as daft about Andrew as ever isn't he?
It shows a little bit, not in Jack, I don't mean in Jack I mean in Andrew.
It shows in both of them.
I mean Jack was so solicitous that
And he and I had oops er had earlier talked about people, no that's fine, that's fine I like the crust, erm parking on verges and I was decrying it.
Of course when we came back and discovered Andrew and co had arrived, he'd parked on the verge and I had a dig at Andrew about it.
Jack was terribly defensive of him.
You know totally changed his tune from earlier .
Well it's better that way round than the other.
Oh you mean the way I treat Snoopy?
That's not what I mean at all.

unclear.c: . No but it's better to have er parents who think highly of their kids even if slightly mistakenly

s.w: We've got two more down there, which are looking very healthy.
I have offered to Lizzie to make bean salad for her wedding reception, or Brian's wedding

pause.w: Erm with the help of David's mother.

s.w: The erm my mother's, David's mother's making a cake, er it was one of those special ones.
What did she say about desserts?
Didn't she say that the college was, they were paying the college to ?
They're having it at the co , at the university because David's mother has some connection.
Which was how she knew about it.
And the desserts I think the college does a very good array or selection or standard or something of desserts.
So they're going to actually buy the desserts from the college.

unclear.w: or something like that, they are.

pause.w: Lydia's doing cold meat and, and salad basically.
Well you're some guard dog aren't you?

s.w: Perhaps she could smell me through the door.
You realize I don't trust him any longer.
All these conversations he has and I'm not there.
Well it's a pacemaker below the belt dear.
Well I don't want to know about that.
Yes I prefer the picture of the Red Arrows personally.
Oh, gosh, we've actually got a message in now.
There was nothing, there was nothing in the mail but a chequebook.
No it's, it's and er about the alloy eight hundred H T.
You didn't telephone Richard's did you?
Well when I find out who it was I shall wring their necks.
Oh well you mean you rushed back in again did you?
No, well no I was actually stark naked in the bathroom.
Oh of course there's no school is there?
I wouldn't mind being M D of an electronics firm.
How many , how many to make you redundant this week.
He's off at he's up at nine o'clock .
No if you think about it he was out er Monday last week .
Monday before that we were away, Tuesday away playing golf.
And today all day he plays golf.

ptr.w: I think he might get a bit of a a a a bit of a reaction from one or two of these people, don't you?

s.w: This eight hundred H T order's slipped away.
Not too surprising really I suppose but erm I went up and erm heard the jazz at the Crown last night.
In fact I was quite a busy little bee last night.
Fixed to go and have a game of croquet on Saturday afternoon.
Oh you said you were, you were threatening to do that weren't you?
Shall I put the kettle on?
I wouldn't er, I wouldn't trust her with mallet.

vocal.w: Oh I've got bags of time I reckon to make notes on what I'm doing as we talk here.

s.w: Yes, oh yes it's all sort of, relatively complex stuff.
You, you read that did you?
Did they send you the Walkman as well?
And I've got boxes of, two boxes of tapes.
Yeah, I mean you're not particularly trad jazz inclined anyway are you?
Oh I like trad jazz I don't like modern jazz at all.
But I like trad jazz I mean that was, there was a great, there was a trad jazz era in the sixties
I had a chat with him last night.
And er he sort of admitted that he lives absolutely on the fringe of the no go area.
Mm look at it, I mean the name of his house Wit's End.
Out of interest, how much do you charge for your do?
Erm no I didn't, Plum actually did the organizing.
I think, I think it was about two hundred and forty pounds
but don't quote me on it.
It might have been more it might have been
Somebody mentioned the figure of three hundred pounds.
It sounds a bit of a
I don't know but that, that price, somebody in conversation mentioned it.
But they, of course they may be now cos we booked them back in Feb
But they were only relatively cheap because at the time I made that change musician union.
So they weren't charging union rates and we got them relatively cheap.
Maybe whoever was telling me was making a
Well when you look at how busy a programme they've got.
You can't, it's difficult to believe why they don't charge full whack.
I mean it was very interesting in the Crown last night because apparently they, they normally have some rhythm and blues and soul and things like that on a Thursday.
And erm the youngsters weren't objecting to their music.
I mean there were no real teeny boppers.
Erm but the the old grey hairs like me were leaping around and .
I was rather irritated yesterday because I had a phone call from
And he called Gary saying we don't have the P elevens.
And I I said oh well that's fair enough so I dug them out and sent them to him.
And after I'd stamped and sealed the envelopes he rang back he said I haven't got the copy VAT certs either.
I was not pleased at that!
And I, wouldn't have occurred to me to send the P elevens.
Actually that's not true either because I sent the P elevens to Steve and Matthew for his approval before we sent them off.
And he sent them back again?

pause.w: I don't know whether he sent them back.

s.w: I sent , I didn't send him the originals I sent a copy.
I doubt that he sent them back.
Oh well, I I've sent the ones from the drawer
off and said I want them back!
We haven't got copies of them .
That that, well you know if there's a query in the next fortnight we know where they are don't we?
But I was annoyed and I thought well that's fair enough because I wasn't aware that those particular documents were required by the accountants to sort things out, but
I didn't ask him but he said he required them.
But I know that copy VAT certs, the VAT certs, VAT payment return, returns that's what they're called aren't they, are required.
And so we hadn't sent them.
Well they're here in the drawer where they're kept.
There's there's a VAT file in there and that's where they get put.

pause.w: Bit silly isn't it?
This is a unhelpful because it's winding that way yet it looks as if it's winding that way, doesn't it?

s.w: It looks as if it's reeling on to that spool.

ptr.w: But it's reeling onto that one?
It's not it's reeling through there.

s.w: Very confusing and the fact that they've stuck that label on there doesn't help very much either.
No, so, when it's full you have to put another tape in, does it
I thought it would actually reversed on the first side.
Yes and I thought it was mucking it up so I just swapped it over the way it was.
Well it it tells you quite a lot, but it doesn't actually mention that bit.
I've got, I have got oodles of instructions here.
I'm going to Eltham to get some material I hope.
No there's nothing else I need thank you.
She could use a Mars Bar you could.
You could just sort of tuck it in here under her waistband.

pause.w: Save her swallowing it.

unclear.w: Dorothy was saying on the radio there was a programme about teeth.

s.w: And they said within fifty years false teeth will be a thing of the past.
Nobody will need to wear them any more.

ptr.w: We probably won't need teeth we'll all be eating gruel all day.

s.w: things to people's teeth and people's teeth today are so much better than the past.
Well it's too late for me.
You haven't got any false teeth.
But I might do in the next fifty years any of them.
Oh we'll feed you on gruel dear don't worry.
You might be needing your own .
What flavour gruel would you like?
I don't think I'll mind really.
No I prefer, I prefer original.

pause.w: Yes alright whisky flavour wheat.
Oh that green looks really gorgeous with your colourful tracksuit dear.

s.w: Well what do we wear with it.
I don't have a purple jacket.

pause.w: How come Graham's playing golf again today anyway?

s.w: He's out officially currying favour ha?
I mean it it's really quite fascinating that isn't it?
They are making the bank a lot of money.

unclear.w: playing golf this morning having a posh lunch and then playing golf this afternoon then having a buffet supper with prize giving.

s.w: Last time he won a beautiful .
Yes, well you'd be cramping his style wouldn't you?

vocal.w: And er he had a partner, an equal partner who I don't know if he'd ever met him, I think he had.

s.w: Well he was out playing golf fairly recently he just dropped dead.

pause.w: keeled over and died.

s.w: I hope it wasn't on the green.
I hope he didn't bleed or anything like that.
I think he, you know, quite clean corpse.
I would have thought it would have put his partner off playing golf for life.
You'd have thought so wouldn't you?
Still I imagine many men would say what a way to go.
Far better way to go than that but
Who knows I might even get a chance to try one of these days.
As long as you don't die with bells on your ankles.
Well then at least I'm they'd bury me with bells on my ankles then.

unclear.w: bills have my name, it's obviously hiding.

s.w: Now erm you did bring a a very good point there Lynda .
Erm which was that erm what was it

unclear.w: remember what, what he said last.

s.w: But I'll see if I can find .
I would have thought that he would have been down slightly more less
Have you a thrilling weekend ahead of you?
And then to the er, I think that's
Well I, I've got a, got to a, got to go and play croquet but apart from that .
Got to go and get another crate of Sam's.
A fairly packed weekend then really.
Did you see the thing, piece in the paper this morning Kew gardens says don't water your plants, we don't.
Yeah, there is no water so don't use it.
Well I've heard it before that a, said, said before that a, that, that the plant roots curl up to the surface to meet, rather than digging down deep and.
Heading for the goodies that way.
From lack of water yes, well our, our, our did, our did to, our er Rosemary.
When you see Di will you mentioned that erm heavy duty office.
I'm seeing her at lunch time, I'll speak to her.
We want, we want that seal it style as opposed to the right, we do indeed, yes a closing, a closing staple.
A staple closer, not just a staple gun.
